channel.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
channel.description:
When I put RSCD's new site up I'm going to host as many polls as possible which will decide the path/route of where the server goes. What would you ask the community?
I need the question and the multiple choice answers, such as:
[b]How should rare items be introduced?[/b]
[ol][li]Manual world drop on the holidays[/li] [li]Dropped by NPCs[/li] [li]Rewards for referral count[/li] [li]Don't drop rare items![/li][/ol]

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @h_e_n_r_y h e n r y
item.description:
@h_e_n_r_y wrote:

how do you do this stuff on a mac

Read full topic
item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“cyndibal, post:87, topic:426381”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=529075.msg3871698#msg3871698 date=1325381365]There is much more knowledge embedded in source code than any discussion you can/will ever have.
[/quote]that the dumbest thing ive ever heard, and who are you to be laying down facts like that you arent the judge here buddy[/quote]…

Source code contains implementation details, optimizations, data structures, ideas, interaction with the rest of the application, etc. Most conversations cover one or two of those, and I’ve never even heard of someone claiming a conversation contains more knowledge than source code.

If you know of a conversation that is more informative than can be extracted from the actual code, then I would absolutely love to see it.

Read full topic
item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

Zilent:

[quote author=Peeter link=topic=529075.msg3869515#msg3869515 date=1325248559]Why is this community filled with hate and why no-one wants to share knowledge.

There’s a difference between sharing knowledge and handing out massive amounts of source code for potential bot-makers to use to their ends.

From my personal freelancing experience, I’ve seen that proprietary systems and API have generally been:

A) More user-friendly (You don’t have to spend hours reading documentation and configuring the solution for use)
B) Much cleaner (A single coding convention is enforced)
C) Much easier to extend and maintain
D) ‘Safer’ in terms of licensing. ( http://dewimorgan.livejournal.com/21650.html )
*To clarify point D, combining your license with the GPL license is ok, granted that it is released under the GPL license.

than open-source alternatives.

Do I seem to be full of hate? I’ve only ever been courteous with all of the members of this community. I’ve never had an issue with granting knowledge, but I have had an issue with granting free source code.[/quote]There is much more knowledge embedded in source code than any discussion you can/will ever have.

Read full topic
item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @Zilent Zilent
item.description:
@Zilent wrote:

Peeter:

Why is this community filled with hate and why no-one wants to share knowledge.

There’s a difference between sharing knowledge and handing out massive amounts of source code for potential bot-makers to use to their ends.

From my personal freelancing experience, I’ve seen that proprietary systems and API have generally been:

A) More user-friendly (You don’t have to spend hours reading documentation and configuring the solution for use)
B) Much cleaner (A single coding convention is enforced)
C) Much easier to extend and maintain
D) ‘Safer’ in terms of licensing. ( http://dewimorgan.livejournal.com/21650.html )
*To clarify point D, combining your license with the GPL license is ok, granted that it is released under the GPL license.

than open-source alternatives.

Do I seem to be full of hate? I’ve only ever been courteous with all of the members of this community. I’ve never had an issue with granting knowledge, but I have had an issue with granting free source code.

Read full topic
item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“cyndibal, post:82, topic:426381”][quote author=CodeForFame link=topic=529075.msg3870653#msg3870653 date=1325311295]

[quote author=The Enforcer link=topic=529075.msg3869434#msg3869434 date=1325236541]

CFF, bots are still around.

Zilent, bots will always be in the rsc community… maybe not at first when the server isn’t worth a shit… but if it proves to be worth while someone is always looking for some $$.
[/quote]The only ones are shitty color based bots, which are much more detectable, and easier to thwart.

Color bots don’t modify the client, the only data that Jagex can look at is bot-like actions like strange mouse movements.

I’m looking forward to see what the anti-bot techniques for this new server will be. If it’s what I think then it will rule out everyone who is only used to Java bots and the client’s class files being available.
[/quote]There are so many ways you can mess with them, which will force constant updates. The behavior of them is not very human like when you have someone messing with the bot.

Mess with what, color clickers? Its not that hard to edit a few lines of autoit[/quote]There are many, many things that can be done that are not noticeable by people, but would screw with color based bots. Look into how the human eyes work, and how to trick them.

As always, the bot fight is about doing as little work possible while forcing the other party to do as much work as possible.

Read full topic
item.source: What questions would you like to ask the community?

I’m looking forward to see what the anti-bot techniques for this new server will be. If it’s what I think then it will rule out everyone who is only used to Java bots and the client’s class files being available.
[/quote]There are so many ways you can mess with them, which will force constant updates. The behavior of them is not very human like when you have someone messing with the bot.[/quote]

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:69, topic:426381”][quote author=Rodgerwilco link=topic=529075.msg3864735#msg3864735 date=1324926841]
CFF, bots are still around.

Zilent, bots will always be in the rsc community… maybe not at first when the server isn’t worth a shit… but if it proves to be worth while someone is always looking for some $$.
[/quote]The only ones are shitty color based bots, which are much more detectable, and easier to thwart.[/quote]

Color bots don’t modify the client, the only data that Jagex can look at is bot-like actions like strange mouse movements.

I’m looking forward to see what the anti-bot techniques for this new server will be. If it’s what I think then it will rule out everyone who is only used to Java bots and the client’s class files being available.

Read full topic

item.description:

So you’re still around. Hope you’ve been well.

You’re close. Making a bot for this should bring you some $$$.

item.title: What questions would you like to ask the community?

item.description:

The source wouldn’t even need to be decompiled :S
[/quote]

Without revealing too much about my design, to make a perfect bot, I believe that it would.[/quote]

Let me guess. You’re going to write a native application that creates it’s own Java VM, sets up a few things and then forwards the execution to the actual client.
